resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.
status.name: Resolved

worklogs.comment:
wesm commented on pull request #4380: ARROW-5403: [C++] Use GTest shared libraries with BUNDLED build, always use BUNDLED with MSVC
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4380
 
 
   Without this change, failed assertions do not cause failed unit tests on Windows as Antoine had discovered today.
   
   The conda-forge test package seems unusable in shared library form so I'm forcing BUNDLED builds on MSVC and removing the hacks in the docs and Appveyor to pass `-DGTest_SOURCE=BUNDLED`
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.

users@infra.apache.org

wesm commented on pull request #4380: ARROW-5403: [C++] Use GTest shared libraries with BUNDLED build, always use BUNDLED with MSVC
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4380#discussion_r287152741
 
 

 ##########
 File path: cpp/cmake_modules/ThirdpartyToolchain.cmake
 ##########
 @@ -1218,26 +1226,44 @@ macro(build_gtest)
         -Wno-ignored-attributes)
   endif()
 
+  if(WIN32)
+    set(GTEST_CMAKE_CXX_FLAGS ${GTEST_CMAKE_CXX_FLAGS} -DGTEST_CREATE_SHARED_LIBRARY=1)
+  endif()
+
   set(GTEST_PREFIX "${CMAKE_CURRENT_BINARY_DIR}/googletest_ep-prefix/src/googletest_ep")
   set(GTEST_INCLUDE_DIR "${GTEST_PREFIX}/include")
+
+  if(MSVC)

wesm commented on pull request #4380: ARROW-5403: [C++] Use GTest shared libraries with BUNDLED build, always use BUNDLED with MSVC
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4380#discussion_r287152855
 
 

 ##########
 File path: cpp/cmake_modules/ThirdpartyToolchain.cmake
 ##########
 @@ -1218,26 +1226,44 @@ macro(build_gtest)
         -Wno-ignored-attributes)
   endif()
 
+  if(WIN32)
+    set(GTEST_CMAKE_CXX_FLAGS ${GTEST_CMAKE_CXX_FLAGS} -DGTEST_CREATE_SHARED_LIBRARY=1)
+  endif()
+
   set(GTEST_PREFIX "${CMAKE_CURRENT_BINARY_DIR}/googletest_ep-prefix/src/googletest_ep")
   set(GTEST_INCLUDE_DIR "${GTEST_PREFIX}/include")
+
+  if(MSVC)
+    set(_GTEST_IMPORTED_TYPE IMPORTED_IMPLIB)
+    set(_GTEST_LIBRARY_SUFFIX
+        "${CMAKE_GTEST_DEBUG_EXTENSION}${CMAKE_IMPORT_LIBRARY_SUFFIX}")
+  else()
+    set(_GTEST_IMPORTED_TYPE IMPORTED_LOCATION)
+    set(_GTEST_LIBRARY_SUFFIX
+        "${CMAKE_GTEST_DEBUG_EXTENSION}${CMAKE_SHARED_LIBRARY_SUFFIX}")
+  endif()
+
+  set(GTEST_SHARED_LIB
+      "${GTEST_PREFIX}/lib/${CMAKE_SHARED_LIBRARY_PREFIX}gtest${_GTEST_LIBRARY_SUFFIX}")
+  set(GMOCK_SHARED_LIB
+      "${GTEST_PREFIX}/lib/${CMAKE_SHARED_LIBRARY_PREFIX}gmock${_GTEST_LIBRARY_SUFFIX}")
   set(
-    GTEST_STATIC_LIB
-    "${GTEST_PREFIX}/lib/${CMAKE_STATIC_LIBRARY_PREFIX}gtest${CMAKE_GTEST_DEBUG_EXTENSION}${CMAKE_STATIC_LIBRARY_SUFFIX}"
-    )
-  set(
-    GTEST_MAIN_STATIC_LIB
-    "${GTEST_PREFIX}/lib/${CMAKE_STATIC_LIBRARY_PREFIX}gtest_main${CMAKE_GTEST_DEBUG_EXTENSION}${CMAKE_STATIC_LIBRARY_SUFFIX}"
+    GTEST_MAIN_SHARED_LIB
+    "${GTEST_PREFIX}/lib/${CMAKE_SHARED_LIBRARY_PREFIX}gtest_main${_GTEST_LIBRARY_SUFFIX}"
     )
   set(GTEST_CMAKE_ARGS
       ${EP_COMMON_CMAKE_ARGS}
       "-DCMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX=${GTEST_PREFIX}"
       "-DCMAKE_INSTALL_LIBDIR=lib"
+      -DBUILD_SHARED_LIBS=ON
       -DCMAKE_CXX_FLAGS=${GTEST_CMAKE_CXX_FLAGS})
   set(GMOCK_INCLUDE_DIR "${GTEST_PREFIX}/include")
-  set(
-    GMOCK_STATIC_LIB
-    "${GTEST_PREFIX}/lib/${CMAKE_STATIC_LIBRARY_PREFIX}gmock${CMAKE_GTEST_DEBUG_EXTENSION}${CMAKE_STATIC_LIBRARY_SUFFIX}"
-    )
+
+  if(MSVC)

   The googletest DLLs have to be put in the same directory as the build artifacts otherwise they won't be found when you run `ctest`

wesm commented on issue #4380: ARROW-5403: [C++] Use GTest shared libraries with BUNDLED build, always use BUNDLED with MSVC
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4380#issuecomment-495730582
 
 
   The normal MSVC builds passed but the static CRT build failed with
   
   ```
   array-test.cc.obj : error LNK2001: unresolved external symbol "class testing::internal::Mutex testing::internal::g_linked_ptr_mutex" (?g_linked_ptr_mutex@internal@testing@@3VMutex@12@A)
   debug\arrow-array-test.exe : fatal error LNK1120: 1 unresolved externals
   [242/323] Linking CXX executable debug\arrow-file-to-stream.exe
   [243/323] Linking CXX executable debug\arrow-stream-to-file.exe
   ninja: build stopped: subcommand failed.
   C:\projects\arrow\cpp\build-debug>goto scriptexit 
   ```
   
   The BUNDLED build in Travis CI is the only one failing but I haven't been able to repro the issue yet locally

   I fear that the combination of dynamic linking and static CRT may be incompatible

wesm commented on issue #4380: ARROW-5403: [C++] Use GTest shared libraries with BUNDLED build, always use BUNDLED with MSVC
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4380#issuecomment-495822445
 
 
   I've been googling about this and it seems that there are potential issues with having different libraries or executable respectively using `/MT` to statically-link the CRT
   
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.
 
For queries about this service, please contact Infrastructure at:
users@infra.apache.org

wesm commented on issue #4380: ARROW-5403: [C++] Use GTest shared libraries with BUNDLED build, always use BUNDLED with MSVC
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4380#issuecomment-495822445
 
 
   I've been googling about this and it seems that there are potential issues with having different libraries or executable respectively using `/MT` to statically-link the CRT
   
   https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/cpp/c-runtime-library/potential-errors-passing-crt-objects-across-dll-boundaries?view=vs-2019
   
   I would be inclined to either:
   
   * do a library-only static CRT build but not run the unit tests
   * disable the static CRT build altogether
   
   To continue to support this build configuration given how few Windows developers we have seems an undue hardship
   
   cc @MaxRis @rip-nsk if you have any wisdom to offer about this situation
   
   * gtest.dll built with /MT
   * arrow_testing.dll built with /MT, linking dynamically to gtest.dll
   * arrow-something-test.exe also built with /MT, linking dynamically to arrow_testing.dll
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.
 
For queries about this service, please contact Infrastructure at:
users@infra.apache.org

MaxRis commented on issue #4380: ARROW-5403: [C++] Use GTest shared libraries with BUNDLED build, always use BUNDLED with MSVC
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4380#issuecomment-495935407
 
 
   Hey @wesm ,
   
   From https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/cpp/c-runtime-library/crt-library-features?view=vs-2019 
   ```
   Using the statically linked CRT implies that any state information saved by the C runtime library will be local to that instance of the CRT. For example, if you use strtok, _strtok_l, wcstok, _wcstok_l, _mbstok, _mbstok_l when using a statically linked CRT, the position of the strtok parser is unrelated to the strtok state used in code in the same process (but in a different DLL or EXE) that is linked to another instance of the static CRT. In contrast, the dynamically linked CRT shares state for all code within a process that is dynamically linked to the CRT. This concern does not apply if you use the new more secure versions of these functions; for example, strtok_s does not have this problem.
   
   Because a DLL built by linking to a static CRT will have its own CRT state, it is not recommended to link statically to the CRT in a DLL unless the consequences of this are specifically desired and understood.
   ```
   
   With above in mind, it sounds reasonable to not run unit tests, but to keep the build configuration just to verify that compilation passes without errors, so someone who will want to build their 3rd party application statically with static /MT linkage of runtime will get library compatibility out of the box.
   The best solution (to avoid partially working builds), seems, is to have fully static build configured with /MT without any dlls linked, if possible.
   
   Please correct me if I have understood something wrong, thanks
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.
 
For queries about this service, please contact Infrastructure at:
users@infra.apache.org

   > I would be inclined to either:
   >    do a library-only static CRT build but not run the unit tests
   >    disable the static CRT build altogether
   
   Same here. If people are interested in fixing the CMake build chain to enable statically-linked tests on Windows, they can submit a PR.

issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

fields.summary: [C++] Test failures not propagated in Windows shared builds

comments.body: Maybe we need to add {{ASSERT_NO_RAISES}} around {{AssertBufferEqual}} as we did in some other tests?
What is ASSERT_NO_RAISES? I can't find it anywhere.

{{ASSERT_NO_THROW(...)}} doesn't change anything here. And besides, it would be a PITA to change all calls to test helpers.

I think that the solution may be to use a DLL version of gtest. However, massaging CMake to use the gtest DLL seems above my level of CMake proficiency.

By which I mean I'm trying the following changes:
https://gist.github.com/pitrou/e107d5ae292db5229a36026e113c867f

and get this cryptic error:
{code}
(arrow) c:\t\arrow\cpp\build-release>cmake --build . --config Release --target install
ninja: error: 'GTest::GTest-NOTFOUND', needed by 'release/arrow_testing.lib', missing and no known rule to make it
{code}
I'm OK to take a look if you can push these changes to a branch
I'm working on something else right now. I think you can just take the gist above + the diff in the report above.
